title.narrative: Restoring Services Supporting Healing Addressing the immediate needs of women and girls in the wake of the Ebola crisis

description.narrative: To address the immediate needs of women and girls during this period, the IRC will focus on four key areas of intervention: (i) Ensure the existence and safe access to services for survivors of GBV; (ii) Tailor services for women and girls to include provisions and support for survivors of Ebola or those greatly affected by the disease; (iii) Improve awareness raising, targeting specific risks to women and girls during this period; and (iv) Support protection and gender mainstreaming of Ebola focused services. The IRC proposes interventions in areas where pre-existing relationships exist and programming can be quickly started: Lofa, Nimba and Montserrado.

description.narrative: Mercy Corps is establishing the Ebola Community Action Platform (E-CAP) which works with Government, local and international partners to coordinate a social mobilization strategy, and operate an umbrella fund to support and coordinate a wide network of organizations supporting social mobilization initiatives at the community-level.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative: To respond to the Ebola virus disease epidemic in Liberia, Mercy Corps will partner with Population Services International to leverage community-based networks and health messaging to contribute to the Ebola social mobilization strategy in Liberia. E-CAP will coordinate with partners on the ground to activate community task forces. The program will invest in training and materials, nationwide digital outreach and mass media communications to enhance awareness and uptake of behaviors which reduce the transmission of the Ebola virus disease.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Economic Recovery from Ebola for Liberia (EREL)

description.narrative: This program will support the most vulnerable households which have been affected by the Ebola epidemic in Lofa, Margibi, Montserrado and Nimba counties through unconditional cash transfers and vouchers for farm inputs. These cash transfers will seek to cover 50% of the food needs of a family of five over eight months in response to food price increases and depleted food stocks due to the crisis. In addition, vouchers for critical agricultural inputs will be distributed for smallholder farmers, specifically to Nimba and Lofa counties. As part of these activities, ongoing monitoring of the quality and quantity of food and input supply, as well as local market fluctuation monitoring will occur.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
Doctors of the World, also known as Médecins du Monde, has been actively working in Liberia for over a decade. At the onset of the outbreak Doctors of the World initially sought to support the Liberian Ministry of Health and Social Work and Montserrado community health and social work teams by providing hygiene supplies, fuel, education materials, logistical and financial support.
Doctors of the World's intervention has since dramatically increased. We are working in the capital, Monrovia to reduce Ebola transmission and to support five health centers with a combined patient population of 600,000.

Principle activities include the following:
1. Train 400 community health volunteers, 25 peer supervisors, and 25 community leaders from Ebola hotspots.
2. Reproduce Ministry of Health and Social Work IEC materials (posters, flyers and charts) to support door-to-door and community awareness and behavioral change activities
3. Provide infection prevention supplies to community leaders for use in community-based prevention measures and drills
4. Provide of infection prevention items to strengthen infection control practices in the five supported health facilities
5. Organize one week long Ebola awareness campaign per month in hotspots
6. Organize monthly monitoring sessions and analysis by Ministry of Health and Social Work and Doctors of the World
7. Ensure close monitoring of infection control standards and related operations in the targeted health facilities
8. Procure emergency medicines, medical and non-medical supplies for the targeted health facilities, based on the average monthly consumption
9. Ensure isolation rooms are established in the targeted health facilities for triage and isolation of potential Ebola patients
10. Ensure continuous provision of health services (maternal and neonatal health, child health, sexual and reproductive health, and mental health) to the 600,000 inhabitants of the catchment area
11. Train health workers on infection control practices and universal precautions standards
12. Give psychosocial support to health care workers

participating-org.narrative: Liberia Ministry of Health and Social Welfare

title.narrative: Sierra Leone: Ebola Response in Koinadugu District

description.narrative:
-Technical support for the District Medical Officer
-Reinforcement of staff in charge of the isolation unit and at primary healthcare centers
-Logistics support for application of national hygienic-preventive protocol
-Mapping of community and religious leaders, traditional healers, civil society representatives, associations and NGOs
-Creation and coordination of Social Mobilization/Health Education Committee
-Training for NGOs' and associations' staff, community and religious leaders, civil society representatives and traditional healers on how to deal with social mobilization and health education
-Social mobilization and health education campaign in Kabala and in the 6 Chiefdoms of Koinadugu
-Supply of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
-Set up an Isolation Unit at Kabala Hospital and build of the new Holding Center in Kasumpe.

In Koinadugu district Doctors of the World Spain is actively engaged in a prevention and education campaign to fight the spread of Ebola. We are additional assisting local health professionals and health centers.

Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Liberian Agricultural Upgrading Nutrition and Child Health (LAUNCH)

description.narrative:
Collaborating with ACDI/VOCA, PCI implements a five year integrated food security program in Bong and Nimba counties in Liberia. The goal of the program is to provide targeted households with sustainable livelihood interventions, health and nutrition services, supplementary feeding for pregnant or lactating women (PLW) and children under two years of age, as well as interventions to increase access to education. LAUNCH is working with approximately 11,000 rural households, including more than 16,000 children and 10,000 pregnant or lactating women. PLW and children under two receive supplementary rations to ensure improved nutrition and health. An additional 115,000 family members benefit from health & nutrition promotion activities. Finally, LAUNCH facilitates the development of local early warning systems, aiming to strengthen community capacity for disaster risk management as well as all of the program's other interventions.
LAUNCH has also now began supporting PCI's Ebola response programs with community mobilization and commodity distribution.
Pregnant and lactating women, children under two years of age, health facility staff, small holder farmers, community members, youth
Prevening Malnutriton in Children Under Two Approach (PM2A), Care Groups, Social and Behavior Change Communication, Community Mobilization, Water and Sanitiation

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Support to Ebola Treatment Unit Project (STEP)

description.narrative: Health care facility support, health care training, critical medical and non-food item distribution, rapid response, protection of vulnerable populations, triage, infrastructure support, child and orphan protection, medical care

PCI is managing the US Department of Defense built Ebola Treatment Unit (ETU) in Ganta, Nimba County. PC will provide a controlled setting where medical care can be safely given to people infected with Ebola. PCI’s role in managing the ETU will include both clinical and non-clinical components. It will include: (i) initial and on-going training of health facility staff in patient care and infection prevention and control (IPC); (ii) supportive monitoring and supervision of day to day operations and maintenance of the highest of standards of operation; (iii) Supply of Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) in collaboration with the MOHSW/WHO; (iv) Support for the collection of data and reporting; (v) Administration of human resource functions and payment of salaries; (vi) Coordination of the activities of the ETU with other institutions and activities involved with the response including the MOHSW at the county and national levels, the National Case Management Committee, the ETU technical advisory sub-committee and WHO technical advisors stationed in Monrovia and Nimba County. PCI will also promote the protection of individuals and families, including unaccompanied minors, at the ETU. The Ganta ETU will be operated in close coordination with PCI’s and other partners’ efforts in the region in community mobilization, the construction and management of Community Care Centers (CCC), contact tracing, and health system strengthening.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Rapid Ebola Awareness, Communication and Training Program (REACT)

description.narrative:
Implementing with Africare, PCI is implementing a six month Ebola prevention program through the extension of PCI's USAID funded LAUNCH program. REACT will work to to prevent the spread of Ebola in Bong and Nimba Counties and support key health institutions in Bong and Nimba to provide safe patient care. PCI will work to mobilize these communities and support them by building the capacity of health care providers in patient care and infection control; reinforce contact tracing and surveillance to stop transmission of disease; and provide Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) and other needed supplies to health centers. REACT will target 795,507 beneficiaries with the restoration of health services paired with community health education and behavior change, and clinical support. Another 1,810 beneficiaries will be reached with the provision of critical non-food items related to clinical support. A targeted 2,800 Community Health Workers will be trained and supported, including 1200 Traditional Trained Midwives and 1,600 General Community Health Volunteers, with a total 636,406 community members utilizing targeted health education message practices. React will also support/rehabilitate 6 health centers, 96 health clinics and 1 health post.
To effectively address the outbreak PCI will be focusing on three components: (i) Proper testing, isolation, and care of infected individuals, and infection control in treatment centers; (ii) Large-scale behavior change strategies that reduce communities’ exposure to the virus and break the chain of transmission. (iii) Effective tracing of individuals suspected of having come in contact with affected persons and monitoring them for symptoms.
Logistics Support and Relief Commodities, Care Groups, Social and Behavior Change Communication, Community Mobilization, Distribution of PPEs,

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
EC3 will work in conjunction with PCI's overall Ebola response activities funded by USAID/OFDA- including activities in the LAUNCH Title II program and OFDA-funded REACT program. Through EC3 PCI will help manage and support Ebola Community Care Centers (CCCs) in Bong and Nimba County and will provide assistance for rapid response efforts. EC3's activities will help slow the spread of Ebola through better isolation of cases and provide a higher standard of care for suspected and confirmed cases. Support activities will include WASH infrastructure for effective isolation and patient care, building the capacity of health care providers in patient care and infection prevention and control (IPC), and partner with other key agencies to provide key Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) and other key supplies to CCCs.
EC3 will mobilize communities and key health partners at the local level to generate consensus and participation in the CCC strategy, identify and train staff and community members in the management of CCCs, provide access to key materials as well as supervision of the CCC management, and reinforce the capacity of nearby health facilities to manage the outbreak and prevent the spread of Ebola through CCCs and upgrading WASH infrastructure.
PCI will be using a geo-referenced data to track elements of the outbreak and the supply of services through CCCs. This will include the use of GIS-enabled mobile phones for use in reporting of case loads and other trends and data from CCCs. The data will be shared with the MOHSW and other partners.
PCI will leverage its existing working relationships with local health staff and health facilities and support trained community health workers to manage the CCCs, as well as mobilize cleaners, security, a community mobilizer and protection officer, and burial teams (in collaboration with broader burial strategies implemented in coordination with the MOHSW and Global Communities).
Training will cover Ebola transmission and prevention, proper patient triage and patient flows for CCCs; IPC,provision of ORS, antipyretics and presumptive treatment with antimalarials and broad-spectrum antibiotics when medical supervision is available; specimen collection for laboratory confirmation of Ebola virus; and psychosocial support for patients, their families, children and the disabled. PCI will also provide psychosocial support to staff and colleagues working at the CCCs.
PCI has worked to identify and address the specialized vulnerabilities and needs of community members related to Ebola since the outbreak began. This includes directly addressing the unique vulnerabilities of women in their roles as caregivers, traditional midwives, and in burial practices, for example. PCI will incorporate these lessons learned and messages into information and awareness materials for individuals attending the CCCs. These materials will address a range of topics, such as unique vulnerabilities to Ebola (such as for caregivers, health providers, traditional midwives, and for those regularly participating in traditional burial practices). PCI will also develop materials (and/or utilize standard materials from other agencies) intended for children and youth on how to understand Ebola and prevent its spread.
PCI will guarantee that all of its CCCs have clear protocols for the handling of unaccompanied minors at CCCs, in collaboration with local counterparts, and will utilize its resources and networks from other USAID-funded programs in the target area to provide follow up for family tracing, re-unification, and reintegration of unaccompanied minors.
Social and Behavior Change Communication, Community Mobilization, Water and Sanitation, Disaster Risk Reduction, Health Training, Commodity Distribution, Rapid Response

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Protect and Empower for Ebola Resilience (PEER)

description.narrative: Households with pregnant and lactating women, children under two, and those affected by EVD.

Through Cash Transfer Programming (CTP), in alignment with Liberia’s seasonal calendar , PCI will respond to the decline in food access and income caused by EVD by empowering people to meet their basic needs through emergency coping strategies that protect their long-term livelihoods, assets and dignity. Cash for Work (CFW), Unconditional Cash Transfers (UCT) and Agricultural Input Vouchers (AIV) will provide affected individuals with the flexible resources needed to spend money according to their needs and priorities, reintroduce income flow by creating short-term work, and support local businesses through the purchase of local items, goods and materials.
unconditional cash transfers, agricultural inputs vouchers, cash for work activities, women to women groups.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Combating Ebola Outbreak in Guinea Through Intensified Social Mobilization and Improved Contact Tracing

description.narrative: Plan International is implementing a 6-month project to support the ongoing effort to combat Ebola transmission in Guinea through intensified social mobilization and improved contact tracing in four Regions, covering the cities of Conakry, Nzerekore, Gueckedou, Macenta, Yomou, Kissidougou, Coyah, Forecariah, Dubreka, and Telimele. Reaching a total of over one million Guineans in ten key prefectures through increased inter-personal and media messaging and improved contact tracing, the project will support the Government of Guinea’s ongoing effort to break the cycle of Ebola transmission and prevent new infections.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
GUINEA
- In collaboration with the International Federation of the Red Cross, Plan is supporting the training of volunteers for the disinfection of public and household latrines, suspected homes, and public places.
- Plan is setting up hand washing systems in schools and publics areas in its intervention zones.
- Plan is supporting the design and implementation of a national communication plan on Ebola.
- In collaboration with the Ministry of Health and its decentralized representations, Plan is actively involved in the design and roll-out of a public health information campaign to make people aware of preventive measures for Ebola through radio, TV, and internet
SIERRA LEONE
- Plan's response is focused on social mobilization and enhanced behavior change, specifically in the following areas:Child Protection in Emergencies: Children affected by Ebola outbreak in Kailahun and Kenema District and other Plan operational districts are protected from abuse and have access to psychosocial and other life saving support (such as food and non food items).Social Mobilization: Children, their families, and community members in Ebola-affected and potentially-affected communities have access to adequate and accurate lifesaving information to enhance their knowledge and capacity to prevent and control the Ebola disease outbreak.Enhanced behavior change: Children, their families, and community members acquire relevant health and hygiene promotion skills and materials and develop the right attitude and practices in order to prevent any further spread of the Ebola disease.
- Plan handed over 200 sets of hand washing facilities to the Moyamba District Youth Council and the Moyamba District Council Representatives to be placed in 200 hand washing locations across the district. The supplies included 200 Veronica buckets, 200 water collecting buckets, 200 stools, and 200 cartons of Saba foam soap.
- In Kailahun, Plan handed over 300 sets of material for hand washing points (including 300 Veronica buckets, 300 receptacles, and 300 wooden stools) to the District Youth Council for distribution to the communities in Kenema District.
- Through the District Health Management team in Bombali, Plan provided 200 sets of hand washing facilities and 15 kg of chlorine.
- In Port Loko, Plan handed over hand washing facilities to the Youth Commission and the DHMT, including 200 Veronica Buckets and water harvesting containers, 15 barrels of chlorine, and 200 stools.
LIBERIA
- As part of the Social Mobilization Technical Working Group, Plan is focusing on Interpersonal Communications (IPC) and Mass Media Activities aimed at raising awareness and sensitizing the Liberian population on the deadly Ebola virus through community and media engagement, using radio as the primary tool.
- In Lofa, Plan has provided various materials to local authorities, including fuel, megaphones, and handwashing supplies to support community awareness activities.
- Plan is actively engaged in the awareness raising through support to five radio stations in Voinjama, Kolahun, Foya, and Zorzor districts in Lofa County. Radio programs include talk shows, radio spot messages, public service announcements in various languages, phone-in programs, special interviews, and updates from the County Medical Health Officer.
- 25,000 health promotion brochures and 10,000 additional posters on Ebola prevention have been produced and distributed across the country.
- A total of 891 community health volunteers have been trained in Zorzor, Salayea, Voinjama, Kolahun, Foya and Vahun in Lofa County. A total of 414 clinical staff have also been trained with the support of Plan. 20 health centers in Lofa County have been provided with medical supplies and disinfectants (chloride, sanitizers, powder soap, and alcohol).

Plan has been responding to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa since the first cases were confirmed in Guinea in March. While our efforts have been primarily focused on interventions in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, our offices in Benin, Togo, Mali, Guinea-Bissau, Ghana, Burkina Faso, and Niger are on alert and participating in local and national coordination meetings with health authorities.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Emergency Ebola Response in Western Guinea

description.narrative: The Relief International (RI) Consortium’s “Ebola Response in Western Guinea” project is an eight-month project designed to limit the spread of EVD in Guinea. The consortium is composed of three international NGOS: Relief International (Prime partner), ACF (Action Contre la Faim) and CECI (Centre d’Etude et de Cooperation Internationale). The project is based on four complementary activities: community sensitization, distribution of hygiene and prevention kits, training of health agents, and contact tracing. The activities targets mainly four prefectures: Kindia, Forecariah, Boke, and Boffa. The project also targets the following prefectures for the health systems and clinical support activities: Coyah, Pita, Dalaba, and Labe. It will benefit 1,200,000 persons. The program -- based upon the three organizations’ complementary expertise in Guinea – incorporates transferability and scalability so that it can be expanded to other prefectures as well as grows to a larger scale.

participating-org.narrative: Centre d'Études et de Coopération Internationales (CECI)

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative: The Solidarity Center builds the capacity of independent trade unions in Liberia to promote worker rights—such as fair wages and safe working conditions. The project has helped workers in the agriculture, mining and railroad construction sectors, as well as domestic workers, advocate for the protection of their rights through collective bargaining. The Solidarity Center has also worked with its local partners to promote a higher minimum wage as part of a new Decent Work Bill. Liberia and Liberian workers face economic challenges and increased unemployment in the post-Ebola context, and unions are pressing for decent work and wages so that families and communities can recover.

The Solidarity Center organizes educational programs and workshops to educate new union members and leaders on basic worker rights, collective bargaining procedures and ways to promote gender equality in the workplace.

participating-org.narrative: General Agriculture and Allied Workers Union of Liberia (GAAWUL)

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Crisis Response with Salesian Missions Liberia - 2014

description.narrative: 4 shipments of food aid and medical supplies (personal protection equipment).

Stop Hunger Now is supporting the Ebola relief efforts of Salesian Missions by shipping food and medical supplies. The Salesians of Don Bosco in west Africa, including Liberia, have opened their learning centers as shelters for children, are providing food and other basic necessities to families in need and are providing medical supplies to several clinics. In addition, the Salesians are launching an Ebola Prevention Awareness Campaign to educate the population about the outbreak. The headquarters for this work is based in Montserrado county but the partners serve the entire country.
children and families effected by Ebola crisis

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Food Security Program with Reach Now International - Liberia - 2015

description.narrative: This shipment is being sent through our partner Reach Now International to their partner on the ground in Liberia--BESTWA. For 6 years BESTWA has been feeding malnourished and starving children in Buchanan, Liberia. The purpose of the program is to meet the basic nutritional needs of children who would otherwise suffer severe, often permanent, deficits mentally and physically. The children in our program are assessed as to their level of malnourishment, stunting, wasting and other criteria to assess whether they are in need of food for health and growth. In addition to feeding the children we provide elementary education for most of those not in school. One of our goals is to have all the feeding children enrolled in elementary school. This particular shipment will be used to address the ongoing needs attributed to the Ebola crisis.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

job-title.narrative: Food Aid M&E Partner Engagement Coordinator

title.narrative: Crisis response with New Harvest Ministries - 2014

description.narrative: 2 shipments of food aid and personal protection equipment.

Stop Hunger Now is supporting the work of New Harvest Ministries in Sierra Leone to reduce the effects of the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone by providing food aid to needy populations. New Harvest Ministries is distributing food to citizens without adequate food supplies in conjunction with Sierra Leone's Ebola Task Force. The headquarters for this work is based in Bo but the partnership serves the entire country.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Crisis Response with Salesian Missions Sierra Leone - 2014

description.narrative: Stop Hunger Now is supporting the Ebola relief efforts of Salesian Missions by shipping food. In addition to providing food and supplies to medical centers and teaching prevention methods, the Salesians of Don Bosco in Sierra Leone have been asked by the government to take care of an increasing number of orphans. They have created an Interim Child Care Centre to receive children who have been affected by the Ebola epidemic. The activities in the centre will include non-formal education, counseling, and rehabilitation therapy. The main aim of the program is to offer immediate support and to reunite the children with their extended families. The headquarters for this work is based in the northern part of the country but the partners serve the entire country.
children and families impacted by Ebola crisis

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Aid to Sierra Leone and W. Africa in the Wake of Ebola

description.narrative: Food and Non-Food Items Distribution Education

Tzu Chi (TC), linked together by UN Under-Secretary-General Dr. Kandeh Yumkella with the Healey Foundation and Caritas, have, with the help and coordination of the 2 stated organizations, distributed the following materials to various communities in Sierra Leone in 2015:
1,512 multi-functional portable beds. 3,530 eco-blankets. 711,000 face masks. 342,000 Latex Examination Gloves. 700 Stethoscopes. 29,390 KG of rice. 7,140 Brown Rice Protein Powder. 1,152 women clothes. 3,000 bowls and spoons. 37,494 Pairs of Shoes. 119,121 Worn Clothing.
In 2017, Tzu Chi will begin to implement a farmer's empowerment and an agricultural education program, as well as vocational training for adults.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
Maintaining a Resilient Zero in Kono District: Investing in Infection Prevention and Control and Environmental Health in Priority Health Facilities.
To provide ongoing support to Koidu Government Hospital and Wellbody Clinic’s Environmental Health Teams in order to bolster their core Infection Prevention and Control functions and ultimately reduce the risk of another Ebola outbreak

This grant will provide ongoing staffing support of Koidu Government Hospital (KGH) and Wellbody Clinic's Environmental Health Teams (EHT) to conduct key infection, prevention and control functions (IPC), which help reduce the risk of another Ebola epidemic and support the maintenance of a resilient zero.
A majority of the KGH and Wellbody EHT staff are Ebola survivors, most of whom lost their livelihoods during the outbreak. PIH has chosen to hire survivors on their staff in order to address this challenge. The grant will support this vulnerable population, whose ongoing needs not only include livelihoods support, but also primary and secondary health care access, specialized health care services for a range of health challenges, and reintegration and psycho-social assistance.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
The Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) has made significant, if uneven, progress over the last decade addressing Trafficking in Persons (TIP). Threatening this progress, the Ebola outbreak created unforeseen difficulties that left Sierra Leoneans more economically fragile, lacking food security, and vulnerable to the tactics of traffickers.
That’s where the WHI Recovery Centre project makes a difference. The Recovery Centre provides comprehensive and safe residential care for survivors of human trafficking.
Sierra Leonean stakeholders (GoSL, Sierra Leone Police, NGOs, etc.) continue to identify and refer TIP survivors to the TIP Recovery Centre.

participating-org.narrative: Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons (DOS/GTIP)

activity-date.narrative: Planned end date of the activity
Planned start date of the activity

description.narrative:
According the Centers for Disease Control, the 2014 Ebola epidemic was the largest in history. Since the first reported case in March 2014, the outbreak claimed thousands of victims. While it affected multiple countries in West Africa, Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone experienced the greatest number of infected cases and casualties. World Hope International has been operating in Sierra Leone since 1996, fostering an expansive network of rural communities, which helped to tackle the outbreak at a local level.
As one of the largest US-based NGOs working in Sierra Leone during the outbreak, WHI partnered with the Ministry of Health, CDC, UNICEF and UKAID and others to fight the disease on many fronts – from turning trucks into ambulances, to setting up isolation units, to flying a Registered Nurse from the US to Freetown to train health workers, to helping with burials and delivering food, to providing care for shunned survivors, to creating and maintaining Community Care Centers, the team on the ground worked tirelessly to fight the disease. One example of an ongoing program that directly benefitted the Ebola-stricken area is the Affordable Greenhouses program, a partnership with Penn State’s Humanitarian Engineering and Social Entrepreneurship Program (PSU-HESE), which targets the growing food insecurity problem in Sierra Leone. Introduced prior to the Ebola outbreak, the program utilizes WHI’s existing network of Village Cooperatives organized through their Outgrowers Project and provides women smallholder farmers an opportunity to learn how to build Affordable Greenhouses, use them to grow vegetables year-round and capitalize on employment and income generation opportunities. This was particularly important during the outbreak as food scarcity became an issue.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

description.narrative:
In Sierra Leone, 94% of the population does not have access to electricity due to poor infrastructure and unaffordability. Without clean, affordable and reliable electricity, areas like education, health, and communications are negatively impacted.
To address this issue, WHI and Mobile Power Ltd., a small UK start-up, partnered in 2016 to provide clean & affordable energy to the beyond-the-grid population in Sierra Leone. As part of our program, we provide portable battery systems that are powered by solar energy to deliver clean energy at an affordable price. The smart-battery rental system, designed by Mobile Power, is available at local shops and provides users with sufficient clean energy to charge mobile phones and power bright LED lights.
WHI and Mobile Power launched the first Mobile Power Sierra Leone site in 2016 in Pate Bana, a village heavily impacted by the recent Ebola outbreak. The pilot was the first chance to test pricing and customer demand and to make sure the technology and business model would thrive in Sierra Leone. The program provides a low-cost, highly scalable business model with a healthy return on investment for shop owners.
Thanks to this partnership with Mobile Power, WHI is: (1) providing solar-powered lighting and power through smart battery pack technology; (2) improving local economic development through opportunities for entrepreneurs and micro-enterprises, and (3) increasing awareness and utilization of solar energy technology generating jobs.

activity-date.narrative: Planned end date of the activity
Planned start date of the activity

description.narrative: Functioning, clean and safe hospitals are vital to a country’s health advancement. Since 1996, World Hope International has been involved in numerous efforts to improve hospital conditions in the countries in which we work. From providing infrastructure developments and generators to Zimba Mission Hospital in Zambia to building and financially supporting the Wesleyan nursing school in Haiti, to financing salaries and supplies and equipment at Kamakwie Wesleyan Hospital in Sierra Leone to keep staff employed, World Hope International believes in the importance of improving hospitals to improve the overall health of an entire country. Currently, WHI’s hospital improvement work is focused around our Ebola prevention and treatment efforts in Sierra Leone. For example, WHI, in partnership with General Electric and Project HOPE, provided four Clinics in a Can(CIC) to remote regions of Northern Sierra Leone. Retrofitted with solar power and operated by Kamakwie Wesleyan Hospital and the Sierra Leone Ministry of Health, these 20-foot CIC’s operate off the grid and provide much needed healthcare access to more than 10,000 people. In addition, WHI, with funding from UKAID, was able to transform and help re-open the Makeni Government Hospital in Sierra Leone, which was originally declared unsafe and shut down in December 2014 due to poor infrastructure and a lack of infectious disease education among staff.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity

title.narrative: Supporting Primary School Girls and Children with Disabilities in the context of the Government’s Ebola Transition and Recovery Plan

description.narrative: This programme provides targeted support to up to 7,477 girls and children with disabilities in six operational districts – Bo, Kenema, Kailahun, Tonkolili, and Kambia - helping them return to and remain in formal education after school closures caused by the Ebola crisis disrupted their access to education. The project engages with these children directly, through bursaries and study-groups; with their schools, through support to protection, psycho-social services, and accelerated learning core content roll-out; with their communities through social mobilization; and with the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology for more inclusive schools and improved access to education.

participating-org.narrative: Association for the Well-Being of Rural Communities & Development (ABC-Development)

mailing-address.narrative: International Rescue Committee 122 East 42nd Street New York, New York 10168-1289 USA

title.narrative: Maintaining a Resilient Zero in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Implemented by a consortium of partners, this project works to improve Sierra Leoneﾒs capability for early detection and response to Ebola virus disease (EVD) and other public health emergencies. Working with District Health Management teams (DHMTs) and other partners to strengthen Sierra Leoneﾒs Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response System (IDSR), consortium partners provide technical and operational support to enable prompt and effective detection and response to communicable disease outbreaks, including EVD.

participating-org.narrative: DfID - Department for International Development UK

title.narrative: Lesson Plans and Training of Teachers (SSEIP)

description.narrative: This project is part of the UK Department for International Development's support to the President's 10-24 month Post-Ebola Recovery Priorities in Education, provided through the new Secondary Education Improvement Programme (SSEIP), the goal of which is to improve the learning outcomes of more than 1.4 million boys and girls in Sierra Leone by 2020. Implemented by an IRC-led consortium of partners, the project's objective is to contribute towards the improvement of learning conditions in the country by developing simple-to-use and high quality lesson plans for Language Arts/English and Mathematics teachers across all grade levels, and training teachers on the use of the lesson plans.

mailing-address.narrative: International Rescue Committee 122 East 42nd Street New York, New York 10168-1289 USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to SAVE THE CHILDREN FUND
Disbursement to SAVE THE CHILDREN FUND

title.narrative: Impact of Community Engagement on Infection Prevention and Control Measures for Ebola Preparedness in Western Uganda

description.narrative: The IRC will design and implement a community engagement intervention, including activities such as regular communication with communities, establishment of community-based focal points, partnering with local community-based organisations, and formation of community feedback mechanisms. The primary outcome of this research is improved Infection Prevention and Control Measures (IPC) in health facilities in western Uganda, through building accountability and strengthening relationships between health facilities and local communities. This will be demonstrated by improved measurable IPC scores in facilities during preparedness, changes in behavior and perceptions / awareness of Ebola virus disease and increase in Ebola preparedness activities (such as creation of isolation areas at health facilities) in the targeted health facility catchment areas.

mailing-address.narrative: International Rescue Committee 122 East 42nd Street New York 10168-1289 USA

title.narrative: Oxfam donor supported project to advance Post-Ebola Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) for Children and Women in Urban Liberia-LR

description.narrative: Oxfam donor supported project to advance Post-Ebola Water, Sanitation & Hygiene for Children & Women in Urban Liberia including needs assessments to develop activities for improved access, infrastructure and increased coordination among local actors.

title.narrative: Equipping a New Kakata Primary Health Center

description.narrative: In December 2014 at the height of the ebola crisis HWHL made the critical decision to accelerate the construction of a new health center, filling a major gap in health infrastructure in Margibi County. This large, purpose built facility, once operational will provide comprehensive basic medical and dental services, including a secure pharmacy, labs, and imaging. We are working with the Ministry of Health for certification of the facility by the end of August.

mailing-address.narrative: Nanci Cole, 2515 Park Place, Colorado Springs, CO 80904, United States

title.narrative: Beat Ebola By Building Accountability in Liberia

description.narrative: Liberia is recovering from the worst Ebola outbreak of all time. We are working with thousands of Liberians in some of the poorest communities in the country and need your help to make sure a health crisis like this never happens again. For many years we've worked on the ground through our Community Justice Teams (CJTs) to build the trust and accountability that is critical to improve lives-- now help us to scale up the CJTs and build a better future for Liberia.

mailing-address.narrative: Jean Scrimgeour, 1110 Vermont Ave NW, Suite 500, Washington, District of Columbia 20005, United States

title.narrative: Empowering Ebola Orphans in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Hundred of lives were lost during the 2014-15 Ebola epidemic in Sierra Leone. The extended families of the destitute orphans have not been able to care for them financially. We are providing support to these orphans monthly - including food, clothing, school-related expenses, and psycho-social support/counseling. The kids are encouraged to dream again and taught that they can be and do anything. This support is giving them a brighter future, ensuring they do not end up in undesirable lifestyles.

mailing-address.narrative: Sylvester Renner, 1906 Knob Creek Road, Suite 3, Johnson City, Tennessee 37604, United States

description.narrative: IN THE WAKE OF THE RECENT EBOLA CRISIS we believe there is a clear opportunity to foster positive change out of this devastating health disaster, by providing forums for self expression and peaceful debate through the medium of documentary film. In 2016 we launched the WeOwnTV Filmmaker Fellowship a regional film fund a regional film fund and professional development program supporting the production of independent documentaries directed by Guinean, Sierra Leonean and Liberian filmmakers.

mailing-address.narrative: Banker White, 90 Mirabel Ave, San Francisco, CA 94110, United States

title.narrative: Stop Ebola: What you can do

description.narrative: *See reports for most recent updates* In response to the ongoing Ebola epidemic, this project will train BRAC's all-female frontline force of 400 community health promoters to stop the spread of the virus in remote communities in Sierra Leone. These women, trained by BRAC, are known in their own communities and are going door to door, educating people on how to prevent Ebola and recognize symptoms. But they need funding to pay for flyers and leaflets, food and travel costs, and disinfectant.

mailing-address.narrative: Walid Sghari, 110 William Street, 29th Floor, New York, NY 10038, United States

title.narrative: Help Us Stop the Ebola Crisis in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Health officials say the Ebola outbreak, centered in West Africa, is the deadliest ever with over 1,093 infected and almost 500 of those from Sierra Leone. Greatest Goal Ministries operates a free outpatient hospital in Lakka. The military has set up Ebola isolation tents directly outside the doors of our hospital. This project will provide the desperately needed supplies and protective clothing for health care workers as well as support information materials needed for the community.

mailing-address.narrative: Carolynn (Lynn) Pelton, 3410 126 Ave. NE, Bellevue, WA 98005, United States

title.narrative: Help MSF Battle the Ebola Outbreak in West Africa

description.narrative: As the Ebola outbreak continues to spread, with 1,093 cases and 660 deaths now reported across west Africa, Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) is stepping up its response in the most affected areas.

mailing-address.narrative: Corporate Donations, 333 Seventh Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10001, United States

description.narrative: From December 2013 to January 2016, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea experienced the most lethal Ebola outbreak on record. It was the first large-scale outbreak of the virus in the region and communities are still recovering from the epidemic.

mailing-address.narrative: Britt Lake, 1110 Vermont Ave Suite 550, Washington, D.C. 20005, United States

description.narrative: Liberia suffered the worst outbreak of Ebola in recorded history. Accurate information is one of the primary ways to slow and ultimately stop the spread of this horrible disease. Donate now and help us continue to support grassroots organizations to mobilize, educate and bring accurate information into their communities to prevent the further spread of the Ebola Virus. Local communities have been the first responders so let's continue to help them keep their communities safe by supporting them!

mailing-address.narrative: Williametta Saydee-Tarr, Doe's Apartment Building, 2nd Floor Suites, Congo Town, Monrovia, Montserrado Liberia

title.narrative: Info Saves Lives: Ebola Outbreak in West Africa

description.narrative: The deadly Ebola outbreak in West Africa - the worst in recorded history - has so far claimed more than 7,800 lives. At Internews, we believe that during a public health emergency like this one, people need quick, free and reliable information about the disease and how to prevent it. Please help us to ensure that communities at risk, and especially those living in remote rural areas, get the right information now: how to identify early symptoms, prevent transmission, what to do and where to go.

mailing-address.narrative: Amanda Frankel, 1640 Rhode Island Ave NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 95518, United States

title.narrative: Responding to the Ebola Outbreak in West Africa

description.narrative: International Medical Corps is currently in Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Liberia, Mali and Sierra Leone, and is one of a handful of international NGOs that is treating Ebola patients in West Africa. The WHO has reported over 27,500 cases and 11,200 deaths across West Africa. We are committed to getting to zero cases, and to rebuilding and strengthening the local and regional health systems; engaging community members in recovery through outreach and education programs; and bolstering preparedness.

mailing-address.narrative: Davis Nordeen, 12400 Wilshire Blvd., Suite 1500, Los Angeles, CA 90025, United States

title.narrative: Keeping Kakata Liberia Safe From Ebola

description.narrative: When the local hospital closed and the government shutdown in July, our clinic was overwhelmed. Other health workers in Kakata ran away, but our staff stayed and continued the work. Since that time, as the hospital has reopened and closed a number of times, we have continued to build for the future. We have laid the foundation for a new Medical Center. With the help of a grant from Global Giving, we just recruited 10 new Community Health Workers bringing our total to 20. Looking ahead.

mailing-address.narrative: Nanci Cole, 2515 Park Place, Colorado Springs, CO 80904, United States

title.narrative: After Ebola, Gardens Help Rebuild Lives

description.narrative: In a country where so many already lived on less than $2 a day, Ebola's truly crippling longer-term impact is on the whole population's ability to earn a livelihood and feed their families. The epidemic has caused missed planting and harvesting seasons, price spikes, and food shortages. Working with three in-country partners to reach those most isolated by poverty and disease, we are providing more than 25,000 packets of tested, appropriate vegetable seeds, along with support and training.

mailing-address.narrative: Peter Marks, PO Box 9163, Asheville, NC 28815, United States

title.narrative: Lifesaving Information: Halting Ebola in Liberia

description.narrative: The deadliest Ebola outbreak in history has already claimed almost 7,000 lives in West Africa - 70% have been women. Accurate and timely information for public health campaigns is a key to halting the spread of the virus. Through the distribution of our solar and wind-up emergency radios, people living in isolated areas will be able to access information 24/7 to combat rumor and misinformation and learn facts on how to protect themselves and what to do if they suspect someone is infected.

mailing-address.narrative: Kristine Pearson, 76 Arnold Street, Observatory, Cape Town, South Africa 7925, South Africa

title.narrative: RESCUE DOGS in FLOOD AREAS - SAVE CHILDREN'S LIVES

description.narrative: Non-stop storms have physically devastated Philippine cities and rural villages. A lack of nutrition and medicines/vaccinations has posed dangerous survival conditions for both children and homeless pet animals. Diseases like rabies, leptospirosis, and related forms of the medieval "plague" rival Ebola in Africa. Asia America Initiative has provided emergency food and medical care to more than 100,000 people in the flood zones. We are expanding our life saving missions to include 500 dogs.

mailing-address.narrative: Albert Santoli, 1523 16th Street NW,, Washington, DC 20036, United States

title.narrative: Prevent the spread of Ebola in West Point, Liberia

description.narrative: The most densely populated slum in the Republic of Liberia, West Point is home to an estimated 60,000 women, men and children. A single confirmed case of Ebola could be completely devastating to the entire community. Preventing the spread of the disease from the remaining population would be extremely difficult.

organisation.narrative: West Point Women for Health and Development Org.

description.narrative: The Ebola Rural Community Awareness Raising Project is designed to mitigate the spread of the deadly Ebola disease in 75 village communities, this will be done by strengthening and building the capacity of community health structures (Community Health clubs) to help disseminate EBOLA sensitization massages from village to village using IEC materials. It is expected that at the end of this project, communities would be able to manage their own community preventive health problems.

title.narrative: Using Video Education to Avoid Getting Ebola

description.narrative: Proper information is keen in enabling people to avoid contracting the deadly Ebola Virus, so providing the easily understandable messages to the people will help to stop the outbreak. We will use video Education in local languages to conduct interpersonal awareness on how to prevent getting the deadly viral disease using with mobile projectors.
